node.title: Difference in timestep (Local Machine Vs. HPC)
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I am trying to run my phase field simulation on HPC. I observe that the timesteps in HPC is different than what I see on my local PC.
Following are the 1st successful convergence (timestep) result
MOOSE Version:           git commit 7921af52de on 2024-07-02
LibMesh Version:         
PETSc Version:           3.20.3
SLEPc Version:           3.20.1
Current Time:            Thu Jul 25 02:03:35 2024
Executable Timestamp:    Wed Jul 24 15:34:57 2024

Checkpoint:
  Wall Time Interval:      Every 3600.000000 s
  User Checkpoint:         Outputs/checkpoint
  # Checkpoints Kept:      2
  Execute On:              TIMESTEP_END 

Parallelism:
  Num Processors:          1
  Num Threads:             1

Mesh: 
  Parallel Type:           replicated
  Mesh Dimension:          2
  Spatial Dimension:       2
  Nodes:                   6561
  Elems:                   6400
  Num Subdomains:          1

Nonlinear System:
  Num DOFs:                196830
  Num Local DOFs:          196830
  Num Constrained DOFs:    4830
  Local Constrained DOFs:  4830

  Local Constrained DOFs:  322
  Variables:               "bnds" { "unique_grains" "var_indices" } "phi" { "error" "bound_adapt" "errorfrac" 
                             }

Execution Information:
  Executioner:             Transient
  TimeStepper:             IterationAdaptiveDT
  TimeIntegrator:          BDF2
  Solver Mode:             Preconditioned JFNK
  PETSc Preconditioner:    hypre boomeramg

and following is on HPC.

Thanks
Ashish

Hello
The moose commit version is three months older jn the second log.
It also looks like the initial residual evaluation behavior is different between the two runs because only one of them output the warning
Guillaume

Hello,
Can you suggest any changes I should do?
I would say update moose on the HPC to see if you can match the better result on your local machine

node.title: Error when submitting PBS Batch Job to bitterrrot
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
Hello! I am trying to submit a batch job on Bitterroot using the module:
load use.moose moose-containers moose
moose-shell

When I submit my batch job using qsub wombat1.pbs I get this error:

My bash file is attached below:
#!/bin/bash
#PBS -N wombat_job
#PBS -l select=1:ncpus=48:mpiprocs=48
#PBS -l walltime=02:00:00
#PBS -P moose
cd $PBS_O_WORKDIR

module load use.moose moose-containers moose
moose-shell
mpirun ./wombat-opt -i /home/eggejohn/lemhi/projects/wombat/input/07-24/test.i

The issue appears to be with wasp, I tried rebuilding wasp and petsc, I also tried to clobberall in my application file. Any ideas where this issue comes from?
I just found this issue as well, where can I find the list of cluster names?

https://hpcweb.hpc.inl.gov/home/pbs is a dead link

Weird.
is wasp built under moose then?
what does ldd wombat-opt return? so we can see where wasp is?

Here is what it returned, looks like it doesn't exist...

        libwasphit.so.04 => not found

well that's the problem. Whichever wasp was used to build the executable isnt found anymore.
Let's find it, (maybe in moose/something?) then add it to the LIBRARY_PATH environment variable

I accidentally named the folder Lemhi instead of Bitterroot. Does that matter?

no, not at all.
I've been going through all my MOOSE folders and can't seem to find it. Is there a good way to search a directory on the ondemand file browser? Is there a way to re download it?

you can use find on a file starting with libwasp
no there is no way to re-download it. it has to be built

#!/bin/bash
#PBS -N wombat_job
#PBS -l select=1:ncpus=48:mpiprocs=48
#PBS -l walltime=02:00:00
#PBS -P moose
cd $PBS_O_WORKDIR

module load use.moose moose-containers moose
moose-shell
mpirun ./wombat-opt -i /home/eggejohn/lemhi/projects/wombat/input/07-24/test.i

The above will not work due to moose-shell not exiting. It would be like doing this:
> cat pbs_script.sh
#!/bin/bash
echo hello
bash
echo world

> bash testing.sh
hello
> 
To echo what @loganharbour said below, we are actively trying to make this a possibility.
Excuse my incompetence as an engineer; I don't see what's wrong with either script. Can you clarify?

on the "bash" step in the script, it will never return. It just opens a bash shell and stays it in
same for the "moose-shell" step in yout script

The containerized application binaries located under use.moose moose-containers are still a work in progress. While we are discussing them here in an attempt to assist users, they're still undocumented and changing significantly. Secondly, they're meant for executing the application, not for building another moose based application.
To sum it up, this is not the intended use case for the modules that you're loading. We are actively working on a containerized development environment that will work with what you're trying to do, but it has not been released yet.
Thank you so much. I am anticipating this new release!

node.title: cstdlib error in Tutorial 1
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 I have consulted the Posting Guidelines.
 I have searched the Discussions Forum and MOOSE Framework Troubleshooting and have not found what I was looking for
 Q&A Getting Started is the most appropriate category for my question (trouble installing, beginner user, ...)

Issue or question about MOOSE
I believe I am having the same issue as #25567 (but I do not think it was resolved)
I am trying to do Tutorial 1, and upon creating new files for the new custom Kernels make no longer works (with the same error thrown).
I am on this part of the tutorial:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/examples_and_tutorials/tutorial01_app_development/step05_kernel_object.html#source-demo

node.title: CO2 multiphase flow coupled with Geochemistry
node.bodyText:
Hi,
Please I am trying to simulate sCO2 storage in an aquifer with a complex brine composition (i.e. has NaCl, HCO3, K, Ca etc).  I want to simulate the CO2 dissolution into the aqueous phase as well as the subsequent geochemical reactions in the aqueous phase with rock formations. Could you give me some pointers on how to do this?
I tried using the GeoTes example as a template, though the Geochemistry file setup was straightforward, the porous flow file setup has not been.

Hello
This should be a relevant example I think
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/porous_flow/co2_intercomparison.html
Guillaume

Not exactly. Though it does have some elements necessary for the setup.
The fluid systems contains 7 components and 2 phases. Phase 0 (Aqueous phase) should contain all 7 components, while phase 1 (gaseous phase) should contain only components 0 and 1 (H2O and CO2). There is only one source term and that is for CO2.
The goal is to use the multiapp transfer to send the change in components at each node to a geochemistry app, to simulate the necessary reactions.

node.title: GenericFunctionMaterial: add and multiply?
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
Dear Moose-Community,
With this post, I would like to discuss with you whether we should add four new (optional) parameters to GenericFunctionMaterial. I am somewhat undecided here: On the one hand, it would make input files shorter and easier to read and require fewer function objects. On the other hand, it would double functionality.
Initial situation
For models in which different material parameters have to be multiplied by the same factor, several functions often have to be defined per material parameter and per element group (e.g. subdomain). In the simplest case, two functions per parameter and subdomain: at least one function with the "original" (non-multiplied) distribution and one for the multiplied distribution. The same applies in the case of addition (parameter value offset).
Possible Solution
The definition of the second function could be omitted if GenericFunctionMaterial could take over this multiplication/addition directly.
This could look like this in the input file:
[./gfm]
  type = GenericFunctionMaterial
  block = 'ThisBlockOverThere'
  prop_names = density
  prop_values = dens_func
  multiply_by_const = 3.9  # constant values to multiply prop_values by (before add)
  multiply_by = 'MyRampFunction1'  # functions to multiply prop_values by (before add)
  add_const = 85.7  # constant values to add to prop_values (after multiplication)
  add = 'MyRampFunction2'  # functions to add to prop_values (after multiplication)
[]

Advantages:

Fewer functions, as the addition/multiplication takes place directly in GenericFunctionMaterial
Shorter input files (easier to read, reduced potential for input errors)

Disadvantages:

Duplication of functionality (the GenericFunctionMaterial can now calculate)
More complexity in GenericFunctionMaterial

Please let me know what you think about this extension to the GenericFunctionMaterial. If this addition makes sense from your point of view, I can try to program it and then submit a PR.
Jörg

Hello
No these four hard-coded operations wont be needed
Can you use a ParsedMaterial preferrably?
If it does not support all you need then we'll need to add that
Guillaume

Dear Guillaume,
Thank you for your answer and ponting to ParsedMaterial.
As good as ParsedMaterial looks to me, it doesn't seem to be able to multiply by another function value.
In the spirit of your answer I would like to explore all possibilities before proposing new code:
Question 1:
As far I understood ParsedMaterial, it can use variables (coupled_variables) and a user-defined FParser-function. But is there a way to use another Moose-Function as input?
Question 2:
I know I can use t to make the function in ParsedMaterial dependent on time. But is there a way to make a Moose variable dependent on time?
This is not working: bla = '${fparse (34 + t)*0}'
Jörg

Hello
Ok I was semi expecting this.
ParsedMaterial doesn't support functions directly.
However it supports auxiliary variables, and ParsedAux supports functions through the use of the functor_names arguments
You should be able to forward things that way into a material property
It would be good to simplify this if you have development time
Guillaume

Dear Guillaume,
In this case, perhaps I should adapt my request? Wouldn't it make more sense to extend ParsedMaterial with the option to access Moose functions and leave GenericFunctionMaterial as it is? (Disclaimer: I haven't looked at the code of ParsedMaterial yet. I have no idea whether this suggestion makes sense).
Jörg

This makes sense.
Happy to support that.
You may want to add functor support instead, this adds support for functions, variables, pps and functor materials.
And this list is bound to expand
Now we have a whish list! When I have time, I'll have a look through the code. I'll close this thread due to fact, the initial question has been answerd. Once again, thanks for your support!

https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/materials/MaterialFunctorConverter.html this should be a good example to look at to create a functor argument
then ParsedAux should show how to add functors to the parsed expression, with all the nice checks

I'm now looking into extending ParsedMaterial with functor support. Here I need some advice: My first approach was to add the parameters "functor_names" and "functor_symbols" to ParsedMaterialBase. While adding the parameters itself is not a probem, I like to check them and call paramError in case something is not right. Due to the fact, ParsedMaterialBase seems not to derive from MooseObject, I cannot call paramError . Shall I move these two parameters to ParsedMaterialHelper (what feels "wrong")? Or shall I make ParsedMaterialBase derive from MooseObject? Or I'm overlooking something?
You can use a pointer to the object (in the code: this), which you can cast as well, to call paramError

I'm sorry, I need more help.
MooseObject * mo_ptr = dynamic_cast<MooseObject *>(this);
gives an compiler error:
error: cannot 'dynamic_cast' '(ParsedMaterialBase*)this' (of type 'class ParsedMaterialBase*') to type 'class MooseObject*' (source type is not polymorphic)

ah too bad.
Ok in the constructor of ParsedMaterialBase, could you start passing a pointer to the class which is building it?
Is ParsedMaterialBase only created as a base class of classes that derive from MooseObjects?  This would let you do a constructor like:
ParsedMaterialBase::ParsedMaterialBase(const InputParameters & parameters, MooseObject * derived_class)
then we could do something like
_derived_class->paramError(

Thank you! This is how I implemented this now.
While advancing with my code, I hit some more problems. I would like to coordinate how best to proceed here. Is it better to ask my questions here in this discussion, or should I better create a PR (as a draft?). Obviosly, this PR will initially be incomplete.
Draft PR is a good idea

Issue: #28220
PR (draft for now): #28221

node.title: Resuming simulation from previous starting point
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I wanted to know if I can resume a simulation with the deformed mesh of an initial simulation (simple stretching of a plate). From this page (https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/porous_flow/restart.html) it mentioned the meshes need to be the same. But after finite biaxial stretching the mesh in the first simulation is a bit different from its original configuration.
Secondly, I wanted to know if it is possible to restart the aux variables instead of the regular variables. The reason for this is that my first simulation is a simple stretching problem, so my variables are just disp_x and disp_y, but the second one is a frequency domain problem where displacements are split into real and imaginary parts like the last example on this page (https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/solid_mechanics/1d_elastic_waves.html).
The other idea I was thinking of is to also split the stretching displacement variables into real and imaginary parts, which would mean applying the displacement BC on the real part only (and setting the imaginary part to 0 on that boundary)? Would that be equivalent?

Secondly, I wanted to know if it is possible to restart the aux variables instead of the regular variables.

it is possible to do this, but you need to use either:

exodus restart
a solutionUO and several solutionIC (for each auxvariable)

I recommend to use Checkpoint restart + the solution UO route

The other idea I was thinking of is to also split the stretching displacement variables into real and imaginary parts,

and solving the fully coupled problem? Both displacements and frequency domain at the same time?

For the solutionUserObject route, the syntax is:
[UserObjects]
  [./soln]
    type = SolutionUserObject
    mesh = cubesource.e
    system_variables = source_nodal
  [../]
[]

Is the system_variables the name of the new variable you want to save it in, or the name of the variable from the previous simulation in the exodus file? Or are they supposed to be the same? If so then I might need to rename my displacement variables from the first simulation so I don't mix them up.
Also, the execute_on set to TIMESTEP_END means that it'll use the last (deformed) shape of the exodus, correct?
Then just to confirm, when I set the solutionIC, it will only use it for the initial condition? I'm asking because in the frequency domain problem, disp_x (and disp_y) are aux variables calculated as sqrt(disp_x_real^2 + disp_x_imag^2). The real and imaginary displacement variables are the ones calculated from the kernel.

The other option I was thinking was to split the disp_x (and disp_y) in the first simulation to disp_x_real and disp_x_imag. Then, on the zero boundary I'd also set both to zero, and on the boundary with a prescribed displacement I'd set disp_x_real to the prescribed value and set disp_x_imag to zero, since that should be equivalent?
Then, for the frequency domain problem that follows it, I would use
	use_for_exodus_restart = true
in the mesh block, and then use
 [disp_x_real]
    order = SECOND
    family = LAGRANGE
    initial_from_file_var = disp_x_real
    initial_from_file_timestep = LATEST
 []

in my variables block (and same for the imaginary and y variables). I was wondering if this approach would be equivalent.

system_variables in the UO is just the variables you want to load. So it's from the previous simulation.
The names do not have to match, the solutionIC / solutionAux take care of mapping

Also, the execute_on set to TIMESTEP_END means that it'll use the last (deformed) shape of the exodus, correct?

do you really need to execute the user object multiple times? I feel like you just need it for initialization?
Your second option seems fine to me.
I would recommend doing both and weeding out any potential error by comparing the two results

Yes you're right, what I meant to say was to set
timestep = LATEST
in the UserObject. Thank you, I'll try them out!

node.title: How to reduce integration points
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
Hi!
I am interested in investigating the impact of Gauss points in my simulation. To do this I need to change the number of integration points in a 2D simulation, with  QUAD4 elements. Is the code below the way to do it, and how do I know the number of Gauss points?
[./Quadrature]
    type = GAUSS_LOBATTO 
    order = FIFTH
  [../]

If its not, is there an easy way to set the number of integration points in the MOOSE code?
Best regards,
Karl

Hello
You ll have to look at the quadrature definition in libmesh
Setting the type and order is the way to do this in moose
Guillaume

Hi @GiudGiud!
Thank you for your answer.
Where can I access this in my moose program? I've found this link:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/docs/doxygen/libmesh/classlibMesh_1_1QMonomial.html
But I don't quite understand it. It looks like some sort of header file in C programming (which I understand MOOSE is written in)?
Is there some instruction page with steps to follow or something? This to show where the correct header file is, and where to change?
/Karl

yes pick a quadrature from this page
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/docs/doxygen/libmesh/classlibMesh_1_1QBase.html
then look at the source code, in C++ or the header.
There is no instruction page afaik. You may find something in the libmesh theory documentation, I've never looked there

and where to change?

you already know where to change in the input file, this is the block you were modifying in MOOSE

otherwise there is this page that I wrote a year ago
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/Executioner/Quadrature/index.html

node.title: The result of a steady free thermal expansion is so weird...
node.bodyText:
Let's consider a beam, with a d = 0.2 side length square cross section, and l = 10.0 axial length. Thermal expansion coefficient is α = 2.0e-5. Stress free temperature and reference temperature is T_r = 300. Temperature is T = 500. All boundaries are free. There are no loads except thermal expansion. It's a very easy question...

So we have this input file
d = 200.0e-3
l = 10.0
[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
[]

[Mesh]
  [gmg]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = 2
    nx = 10
    ny = 10
    xmin = ${fparse -d/2}
    xmax = ${fparse d/2}
    ymin = ${fparse -d/2}
    ymax = ${fparse d/2}
  []
  
  [extrude1]
    type = AdvancedExtruderGenerator
    input = gmg
    heights = ${fparse l}
    num_layers = 100
    direction = '0 0 1'
    bottom_boundary = '99'
    top_boundary = '66'
  []
[]

[Materials]
  [./elasticity_tensor_steel]
    youngs_modulus = 210e9
    poissons_ratio = 0.28
    type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
  [../]
  [expansion_steel]
    type = ComputeMeanThermalExpansionFunctionEigenstrain
    thermal_expansion_function = 2e-5
    thermal_expansion_function_reference_temperature = 300.0
    stress_free_temperature = 300.0
    temperature = temp_jiegou
    eigenstrain_name = thermal
  []
  [./stress]
    type = ComputeFiniteStrainElasticStress
  [../]
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [temp_jiegou]
    family = LAGRANGE
    order = FIRST
  []
[]

[AuxKernels]
  [changshu_wendu]
    type = ConstantAux
    variable = temp_jiegou
    value = 500.0
  []
[]

[Modules/TensorMechanics/Master]
  [all]
    add_variables = true
    eigenstrain_names = thermal
    generate_output = 'vonmises_stress stress_zz'
    strain = FINITE
    temperature = temp_jiegou
  []
[]

[BCs]
[]


[Executioner]
  type = Steady
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_hypre_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'hypre boomeramg'
  nl_max_its = 50000
[]

[Postprocessors]
  [max_x]
    type = NodalMaxValue
    variable = disp_x
  []
  [max_y]
    type = NodalMaxValue
    variable = disp_y
  []
  [max_z]
    type = NodalMaxValue
    variable = disp_z
  []
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
[]

However, the result is...

The result is so weird, right? The displacement from MOOSE is so huge...In my problem, ΔT = T - T_r = 200. Thermal expansion strain ε_th = αΔT = 0.004. It seems that max disp is only ε_th*l = 0.04...The magnitude disp result from MOOSE is e+01, e+02...
Maybe in MOOSE steady solid mechanics calculation, there must be at least a BC to prevent the rigid body movement...So at least I need to set a disp = 0 in the centroid node of the model??
Looking forward to your reply...

Hello
There is nothing holding the beam. So it is just moving around, in the nullspace of all the allowed solutions (moving the beam by 1m to the left does not make the residual increase at all!)
You were on the right track with preventing rigid body movement.
you have to add a bunch of dirichlet BCs (in x y z) to kill translational and rotational modes which you do not care about
Guillaume

node.title: Exporting StateVariables in Exodus Output File
node.bodyText:
Hi Moose Team,
I am a new MOOSE user and currently learning to use the software. I have a question regarding the export of state variables in the Exodus output file.
I am aware of the technique using the AuxKernel system in MOOSE, which involves defining an AuxVariable and exporting this variable with the following syntax:
  [./Ep_eff]
    type = StateVariable
    variable = Ep_eff
    sdv_id = 47
    execute_on = timestep_end
  [../]
However, my problem involves around 100 state variables. Defining 100 AuxVariables and 100 AuxKernels would be very cumbersome. Is there any way to export all the state variables using a more concise syntax in the Exodus output file?
Thank you for considering my query.

Hello
You can create an action with a reduced syntax that programmatically performs this operation for you.
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/actions/Action.html
If you don't want to modify the code, then simply create this length input file with 100x auxkernels and separate it from the main input input.
in the main input file you can do
!include other_input.i

Guillaume
Thankyou Guillaume for your help
